description: In this tutorial, we show how to study the convergence of the size of the grid of k-points using our Web Interface, for the simple case of a total energy calculation performed on crystalline silicon.
title: Exabyte.io Tutorial: Investigate k-points Convergence

youTubeCaptions.text: Create a simulation, by navigating to the job designer page.

Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the workflow tab, and choose the 'Total Energy' workflow by selecting it in the list. <break time='0.5' /> This workflow can be imported from the bank, if it is not already listed.
Review the default values in the convergence dialog, and accept them by clicking 'Apply'.
Notice the sequence of units at the bottom of the workflow editor. Then, open the <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> unit, by clicking it.

Inspect the <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> input files displayed at the bottom. <break time='1.0' /> Notice how the size of the grid of k-points is varied incrementally, to progressively verify if the total energy is well converged.
We now navigate to the 'Detailed View' tab, and tick the 'convergence ionic' option listed there, to monitor the evolution of the energy convergence.
After that, <break time='0.5' /> navigate to compute tab, and set compute configuration. Here, we use one node with four cores.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> set the name for the job. <break time='2.0' /> Here, we call it - Silicon k-point Convergence Test.
Next, <break time='0.5' /> save the job. <break time='5.0' /> It can then be selected and submitted to the compute queue, for execution. <break time='4.0' />
The status of the calculation will change from pre-submitted to submitted, and then to active. Please wait, until the job has finished running.
When the job is finished, open it, to inspect the final results, including that for the total energy.

Then, go back to the Workflow tab, and inspect again the <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> unit, which this time has a different appearance. <break time='1.0' /> Then, navigate to the 'Charts' tab, where the evolution of the Ionic Energy throughout the convergence test can be verified, in the corresponding plot.
